title: Order and Reverence in Worship
shortSummary: 1 Corinthians 11 addresses proper conduct in Christian worship, focusing on issues of headship, gender roles, and the Lord’s Supper. Paul instructs the Corinthian church on honoring God through orderly worship practices and self-examination, emphasizing respect for divine order and reverence for the sacrament.
timeline: c. AD 55-57 - Paul's First Epistle to the Corinthians during his ministry in Ephesus

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle writing to the Corinthian church, providing instruction and correction on worship practices.

keyCharacters.name: Christ
keyCharacters.description: Jesus Christ is presented as the head of man and the ultimate example for believers to follow.

keyCharacters.name: Corinthian Believers
keyCharacters.description: Members of the church in Corinth who are being corrected regarding worship conduct and the Lord’s Supper.

definitions.definition: A cultural practice referring to a woman wearing a veil or covering during prayer or prophecy, symbolizing authority and respect.
Speaking forth God’s message under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, often in public worship.
The Christian ordinance instituted by Jesus Christ to remember His death through the symbolic eating of bread and drinking of wine.
Approaching the Lord’s Supper without proper self-examination, reverence, or faith, leading to judgment.

outline.heading: Paul’s Teaching on Headship and Worship Conduct
outline.description: Paul explains the divine order of headship—God, Christ, man, and woman—and instructs on appropriate head coverings during prayer and prophecy, emphasizing honor and cultural propriety in worship.

outline.heading: Correction on Divisions and Conduct at the Lord’s Supper
outline.description: Paul rebukes the Corinthians for their selfish and divisive behavior during communal meals, highlighting the failure to properly observe the Lord’s Supper.

outline.heading: Institution and Meaning of the Lord’s Supper
outline.description: Paul recounts the institution of the Lord’s Supper by Jesus, emphasizing its significance as a remembrance of Christ’s sacrifice and a proclamation of His death until His return.

outline.heading: Warning and Exhortation for Self-Examination
outline.description: Paul warns against partaking of the Lord’s Supper in an unworthy manner, urging believers to examine themselves to avoid judgment and encouraging mutual care during worship gatherings.

application: Respect God’s established order in worship by honoring biblical roles and practices, including appropriate conduct during prayer and prophecy.
Approach the Lord’s Supper with reverence and self-examination to fully appreciate Christ’s sacrifice and avoid judgment.
Promote unity and humility in the church by putting others before oneself during communal gatherings and worship.
Be mindful of cultural expressions of honor and modesty that reflect biblical principles in worship settings.

keyVerses.text: But I would have you know, that the head of every man is Christ; and the head of the woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the biblical principle of headship that undergirds the chapter’s teaching on order and authority.

keyVerses.text: And when he had given thanks, he brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is my body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse records Jesus’ institution of the Lord’s Supper, central to Christian worship and remembrance of His sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: But let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of that bread, and drink of that cup.
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s call for self-examination highlights the importance of approaching the Lord’s Supper with a repentant and sincere heart.
